channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

image.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition

channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: 25 US cities under curfew as clashes continue
In a sad week for America, Trump has fled from his duty
item.description: This past week has brought tragedy upon tragedy to our nation: the death toll from Covid-19 passed a grim milestone of 100,000 deaths; the brutal killing of George Floyd ignited mass protests in Minneapolis and beyond, and seven were shot dead demanding justice in Louisville.

item.title: Escalating violence sends CNN crew on the run
item.description: CNN's Omar Jimenez and crew run from tear gas as police confront protesters in Minneapolis.

item.title: He walked 1,250 miles in 10 days. India's lockdown left him no choice
item.description: Rajesh Chouhan had walked 620 miles (1,000 kilometers) in five days. His legs were swollen and his blisters had burst. A piece of Styrofoam trash he'd found on the roadside was soaking up the pus seeping from his feet.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic updates from around the world
The Asian billionaire who made a fortune from war
item.description: When Stanley Ho Hung-sun, the man who made Macao a global gambling mecca, died at age 98 this week he was reportedly worth $14.9 billion.

item.title: Yes, there is misinformation in Minneapolis. No, it's not all Russia's fault.
item.description: In coming hours and days you'll likely hear the claims: "outside forces," perhaps even Russians, are mobilizing online to inflame tensions and stoke violence as protests sweep America following the death of George Floyd, the unarmed black man who died Monday at the hands of Minneapolis police officers .

item.title: It's been five decades since 1968, and things are somehow worse
Protester's message for looters: Something is wrong with you
item.description: One protester in Minneapolis said individuals looting during the nationwide protests, in response to the killing of George Floyd, are 'opportunistic' and 'something is wrong' with them.

item.title: NASA, SpaceX launch astronauts from US soil for the first time in a decade
item.description: A SpaceX spacecraft carrying two NASA astronauts soared into outer space Saturday â€” marking the first time humans have traveled into Earth's orbit from US soil in nearly a decade.

item.title: Elon Musk told CNN in 2004 how he could help NASA
item.description: In an early interview with CNN, SpaceX founder Elon Musk explained how he could work with NASA and his vision for the future of space travel.

item.title: Trump's efforts to change the subject have never appeared more blatant
item.description: On Monday, as the nation marked Memorial Day, President Donald Trump mocked his campaign rival for wearing a face mask. On Wednesday, as the national death toll from coronavirus reached a wretched milestone, Trump and his family flew to Florida in an attempted focus on space travel. By Friday, as smoke was lifting in Minneapolis after a night of racial unrest, he announced the United States would withdraw from the World Health Organization.

item.title: How Karen became a meme, and what real-life Karens think about it
item.description: Karen Sun is a far cry from the "Karen" meme that has spread widely over social media in recent years.

item.title: Trump postpones G7 ... and wants to invite Russia, Australia, India and South Korea
item.description: President Donald Trump has announced he is postponing the G7 until at least September and wants to invite four additional countries to the summit: Russia, Australia, India and South Korea.

item.title: Video shows deputy repeatedly punching woman in head
item.description: An investigation is underway after a Michigan sheriff's deputy was seen on video repeatedly punching a black woman in the head, according to the Washtenaw County Sheriff's Office.

item.title: US's only private island available for buyouts starting at $250,000
item.description: For $250,000, Little Palm Island, a resort off the coast in Florida, can be yours.

item.title: How Vietnam kept its coronavirus death toll at zero
item.description: When the world looked to Asia for successful examples in handling the novel coronavirus outbreak, much attention and plaudits were paid to South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong.

item.title: The world's new Covid-19 epicenter could be the worst yet
item.description: For months, Latin America watched the rest of the world suffer as the coronavirus spread. It is a spectator no longer.

item.title: Which international destinations are reopening to tourists?
item.description: Although most governments are still advising against "nonessential" international travel, a host of popular destinations are beginning to ease their Covid-19 lockdown measures and border restrictions and are moving toward welcoming tourists back.

item.title: Cuomo: America a tale of 2 cities in wake of Floyd's death
item.description: CNN's Chris Cuomo says America in the wake of the death of George Floyd is 'a tale of two cities,' and called for 'majority and minority to unite together' in order for the country to be at its best.

item.title: Unarmed Palestinian man shot dead by police in Jerusalem
item.description: An unarmed Palestinian man has been shot and killed by police at one of the entrances to Jerusalem's Old City on Saturday. Israeli police said officers believed the man had a gun and opened fire on him when he refused to stop for them.

item.title: Crashed PIA flight 'black boxes' to be examined in France
item.description: Work on the flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder from a Pakistan International Airlines flight that crashed in Karachi will begin on June 2, French air safety investigators said Saturday on Twitter.

item.title: Michelle Obama: It's up to everyone to root out racism
item.description: Non-black folks also need to help root out racism, former first lady Michelle Obama said this week while speaking out over the death of George Floyd.

item.title: Central America faces major flood threat
item.description: You've heard meteorologists use the terms "polar vortex" and "bomb cyclone" this year. Now you can add "Central American gyre" to your weather vocabulary. This broad area of low pressure, which formed this weekend, is drifting aimlessly between North and South America.

item.title: F1 gets green light to start season with Austrian GP double-header
item.description: The coronavirus-hit Formula One season will finally get underway with the Austrian Grand Prix on July 5, the Austrian government announced Saturday.

item.title: Zookeeper mauled by lions in Australia
item.description: The 35-year-old woman has been hospitalized after being bitten in the head and neck in what one paramedic called an "extremely vicious" attack at Shoalhaven Zoo, according to CNN affiliate 9 News Australia.

item.title: Zuckerberg finally explains why Facebook is doing nothing about Trump's posts
item.description: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg explained Friday night why his company would take no action on posts in which President Trump threatened "looting" in Minneapolis would lead to "shooting." That explanation came roughly 16 hours after Twitter did take action and despite Zuckerberg's having previously told Congress that posts inciting violence would not be tolerated on Facebook.

item.title: Partygoer at crowded pool party in Missouri tests positive for coronavirus
item.description: A person who partied at a crowded Memorial Day party in Lake of the Ozarks, Missouri, has tested positive for the coronavirus.

item.title: Playdates and the pandemic: Can kids safely meet up?
item.description: As states reopen, some parents are relaxing social distancing rules and allowing their kids to play with others. But with scientific research politicized and changing daily, it's hard to tell how risky playdates are and what's safe amid the ongoing pandemic.

item.title: WWII aircraft buried by sand discovered on beach after 76 years
item.description: A British couple have found the wreckage of a crashed World War II fighter jet, believed to be a Bristol Beaufighter TF.X aircraft, on a beach in northeastern England.

item.title: World's deepest octopus captured on film 4 miles below the surface
item.description: The deepest known sighting of an octopus has been captured on film, more than a mile deeper than the previous reliable sighting.

item.title: The racist origin of the phrase Trump tweeted
item.description: President Trump tweeted about nationwide protests over George Floyd's death, saying "when the looting starts the shooting starts." Trump and the White House have since said that the tweet was not intended as a threat. CNN's Abby Phillip reports on the racist history tied to the phrase.

item.title: Monkeys snatch blood samples of suspected Covid-19 patients
item.description: A troop of monkeys snatched the blood samples of suspected coronavirus patients at a government hospital in the Meerut district of the north Indian state of Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: Inside the last of Germany's disappearing nuclear plants
item.description: After an earthquake and tsunami triggered multiple meltdowns at Japan's Fukushima Daiichi power plant in 2011, the shockwaves were felt across the world's nuclear industry. Over 5,000 miles away in Germany, where the use of atomic energy had long been a matter of contention, the incident sounded a death knell.

item.title: Football's restart is a battle of 'money vs. health,' says former Premier League club doctor
item.description: The world's richest football league will return to our screens on June 17.

item.title: Daredevil biker swaps mountains for washing machine stunts
item.description: Most people might look at a washing machine and think it's only got one use.

item.title: As a female footballer it's 'impossible to not be standing for equality,' says Ada Hegerberg
item.description: It doesn't take long to understand what type of person Ada Hegerberg is. One of the world's best female footballers certainly likes to be punctual.

item.title: German scientists hope human excrement can help warn of outbreaks
item.description: German scientists hope that human excrement can help detect early traces of Covid-19. They say traces of the virus can be found in wastewater and could predict potential outbreak areas. CNN's Fred Pleitgen explains.

item.title: 'Space Force' casts Steve Carell in a broad satire that never achieves liftoff
item.description: Reuniting Steve Carell and "The Office" producer Greg Daniels, "Space Force" carries such an impressive payload -- from the star-heavy cast to the concept -- it's a shame the actual show isn't better. As is, this too-broad parody has sporadic moments but consistently feels like it's trying way too hard to achieve liftoff, like an "Airplane!" movie gone wrong.

item.title: This app uses science and tradition to warn African farmers of drought
item.description: An app is combining weather station data with the traditional knowledge of African farmers to predict droughts.

item.title: Preserved ancient Roman mosaic floor found in Italy
item.description: A well preserved ancient Roman floor has been discovered under a vineyard in Negrar, Italy.

item.title: Somehow, things are worse now than in 1968
item.description: Americans are waking up to a new nightmare. On top of a pandemic that has ravaged the country, killed more than 100,000 people so far and shut down much of our economy, there are now mass protests in response to the death of George Floyd, a black man who pleaded, "I can't breathe," as a white police officer kneeled on his neck. With President Donald Trump sending out tweets threatening violence against looters and police arresting reporters on air, it's hard for Baby Boomers not to feel like this is 1968 all over again.

item.title: Protesters break curfew on another night of fury and frustrations
item.description: A wave of protests over the death of George Floyd spread from coast to coast on Saturday night, with crowds breaking curfew in major cities on another night of fury and frustrations.

item.title: Reporter fired on with pepper bullets while on air
item.description: While covering protests in Louisville, Kentucky, an officer fired what appeared to be pepper balls at a reporter for WAVE 3 News, a local TV station. The incident was broadcast live on the air.

item.title: Five-month-old baby survives coronavirus after 32 days in coma
item.description: After spending a month in an induced coma due to Covid-19, Dom, a 5-month-old Brazilian baby, gets to go home and celebrate his 6-month birthday.

item.title: The FBI's top lawyer is resigning
item.description: The FBI's top lawyer is resigning amid renewed pressure from President Donald Trump and Republican allies for the bureau to remove any remaining officials associated with the Russia investigation.

item.title: Denzel Washington helps distressed man
item.description: The Los Angeles Police Department called actor Denzel Washington a "good Samaritan" for helping out a distressed man who was caught in a busy intersection, according to the actor's representatives.

item.title: How will we party post-pandemic?
item.description: In nightclubs around the world, once-crowded dance floors have remained empty for months. If you need reminding, clubbing is close contact activity: People share drinks, hug, kiss and generally invade each others personal space until the early hours of the morning.

item.title: Starbucks 'tastes burnt' but I love it
item.description: On most days I am loyal to my locally owned coffee shop. I spent years working as a barista myself, pulling shots of espresso and pouring silky steamed milk into ceramic mugs -- a wiggle of the wrist to finish it off with a snow-white pattern in caramel-colored foam. My fellow third-wave coffee crafters and I would cringe if someone ordered a tall instead of a small.
